api_reference.title: About Program API
api_reference.description: Integration web service The web services software is built to interact with cardholder information. Whether doing a batch process of accounts via another client application, a real-time web request through the Galileo interface, or a terminal transaction through a closed network, you can use web services to meet a wide variety of needs. Currently, the web services software can handle account transactions with the endpoints defined in this reference. You can request that additional endpoints and modifications be developed at an additional cost. Information provided by Galileo Secure web address Provider ID Provider usernames and passwords Product IDs Information provided by you Business contact Technical contact Connecting provider IP address or address range Interfacing The web service is available on HTTP through an SSL connection. Galileo will provide you with information to get connected.

api_reference.title: Get Product Config
api_reference.description: Use the Get Product Config endpoint to retrieve the product configuration according to the specified section.

parameters.name: prod_id
parameters.description: Galileo-generated identifier for a product. Pattern: Integer Example: 50031

parameters.name: section
parameters.description: The section of the product configuration to retrieve. See Valid section values. You can input only one section at a time. Pattern: String Example: auth_limits

parameters.name: limit
parameters.description: The maximum number of records to return. Default: 20 Pattern: Integer Example: 15

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Which record to return as the first record. Default: 0 (start with the first) Pattern: Integer Example: 5

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description: For {token} insert base64-encoded apilogin:transkey

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: Description of the status code

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: Data returned from the operation, present only if successful

parameters.name: rtoken
parameters.description: Token associated with the request

parameters.name: errors
parameters.description: List of errors that occurred during the request processing

api_reference.title: Rate Limits
api_reference.description: Rate limit Galileo does not specify a default limit on the number of API calls that a program can make; however, it is still possible to overwhelm the system with an excessive number of calls during a given period. You will need to work with Galileo to calculate a safe upper limit for your program. The factors to take into consideration will vary per program and can include things such as core configuration and transactions per account. Failure to conform to this upper limit can result in system failure, with high numbers of request failures and other unexpected negative results. Payload limit For many endpoints the payload for an endpoint request cannot exceed 16 MB. Some endpoints can handle larger payloads; however, overlarge payloads can overwhelm the system. Check with Galileo to verify payload limits for individual endpoints.

api_reference.title: Record-Set Pagination
api_reference.description: Some endpoints return large data sets. Use record-set pagination to control the number of records returned at a time. Pass the number of records per page in the recordCnt parameter. The default maximum is 200 records per page. If you pass a number higher than 200 you will get 200 entries per page. Set the MXRPG provider parameter to increase the maximum number of entries per page or set NOPGE to retrieve all records in one page, irrespective of MXRPG. Each response includes: total_record_count â€” Total number of records found within the search parameters number_of_pages â€” Number of pages available page â€” Current page being returned. To request different pages, pass the desired page number in the page parameter. Wires-related endpoints For the wires-related endpointsâ€”Get Destination Accounts and Get Wire Historyâ€”the pagination scheme is different. Instead of specifying which page to return, you get the first page by default, and then you call the endpoint again to get each subsequent page. Pass a value for recordCount to specify how many records per page to return. Default 100. Max 200. The first time you call the endpoint, leave nextPageToken blank. The endpoint returns the first page of records along with total_record_count. If total_record_count is higher than the number of records on page 1, a next_page_token is provided. If total_record_count is equal to or lower than the number of records on page 1, a next_page_token is not returned. To retrieve the next page of records, call the endpoint again and populate nextPageToken with the value received in the previous call. As needed, repeat the previous step until there are no more pages to return.

api_reference.title: Responses
api_reference.description: The Program API supports two formats for endpoint responses: XML and JSON. Specify which format to receive in the response-content-type field. The raw HTTP request below shows a request for JSON responses. Sample requestPOST /intserv/4.0/ping HTTP/1.1 Host: 10.6.33.31 Connection: close Accept-encoding: gzip, deflate User-Agent: Galileo API Tester Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded response-content-type: json Content-Length: 103 apiLogin=XXXXXX-9999&apiTransKey=XXXXXXXXX&providerId=XXX&transactionId=q3jkzvunwra29zfy9tnhc9gg3rcwcl Default response fields By default, all responses contain these fields. FieldData typeDescriptionSample valuesstatus_codeNumericNumeric code for the status. See Status Codes and Errors for more information.0407-02statusStringThe description of the status_code.Successprocessing_timeFloatThe amount of time in seconds between the call and the response.0.065response_dataObjectEndpoint-specific data. For some endpoints this field is empty. See the individual endpoint response examples.echoObjectContains values that were passed in the original endpoint call.provider_transaction_idStringThe value of the providerTransactionId parameter.provider_timestampDate-timeThe value of the providerTimestamp parameter.transaction_idStringThe value of the transactionId parameter.errorsListContains details about an error. Present only when status_code contains an error code.'achAccountNo' is required and cannot be emptyrtokenUUIDUUID for the endpoint call, generated by the Galileo system. Use this value when troubleshooting specific endpoint calls with Galileo.system_timestampDatetimeDate-time of the response in Galileo system time.2027-04-26 16:12:06 Example response structure Also see responses with status codes and errors. JSONXML{ "status_code": 0, "status": "Success", "processing_time": 0.1671297550201416, "response_data": {}, "echo": { "provider_transaction_id": "", "provider_timestamp": null, "transaction_id": "25570855" }, "rtoken": "8cc16de0-5eda-4e2a-968e-3b08fce6f778", "system_timestamp": "2027-07-13 10:47:34" } <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <root> <status_code>0</status_code> <status>Success</status> <processing_time>0.1671297550201416</processing_time> <response_data></response_data> <echo> <provider_transaction_id></provider_transaction_id> <provider_timestamp></provider_timestamp> <transaction_id>25570855</transaction_id> </echo> <rtoken>8cc16de0-5eda-4e2a-968e-3b08fce6f778</rtoken> <system_timestamp>2027-07-13 10:47:34</system_timestamp> </root>

api_reference.title: Get Card Transaction Fraud
api_reference.description: Use the Get Card Transaction Fraud API to evaluate the risk associated with specific card transactions and understand if a transaction is fraudulent, then take appropriate action based on predefined criteria. This endpoint provides detailed fraud detection insights, including rules triggered, actions taken, and supplementary fraud prevention decisions. See About the Payment Risk Platform for more details.

parameters.name: apiLogin
parameters.description: Web service username, as provided by Galileo. Pattern: Max 50 characters Example: "AbC123-9999"

parameters.name: apiTransKey
parameters.description: Web service password, as provided by Galileo. Pattern: Max 15 characters Example: "4sb62fh6w4h7w34g"

parameters.name: providerId
parameters.description: Galileo-issued provider identifier. Pattern: Max 10 digits Example: "9999"

parameters.name: transactionId
parameters.description: A unique provider-generated ID to identify this API call. A UUID is preferred. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "9845dk-39fdk3fj3-4483483478"

parameters.name: riskServiceId
parameters.description: Unique identifier provided by Galileo during implementation to obtain client PRP configuration details. Pattern: Max 50 characters Example: "EPRP-test-1231231:1"

parameters.name: eventType
parameters.description: Specifies the type of the transaction event. Pattern: Debit Example: "Debit"

parameters.name: eventTs
parameters.description: Timestamp for when the transaction event occurred, in Mountain Standard Time (-0700). See Galileo System Time guide for details. May be the same timestamp as authTs. Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2020-10-28 00:00:24"

parameters.name: personId
parameters.description: Unique identifier of the account holder/customer associated with the event. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "p54789641"

parameters.name: accountId
parameters.description: Unique identifier of your customer account for which the related event is associated with. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "a125483"

parameters.name: cardId
parameters.description: An identifier of the card for which the related event is associated with. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "card_123"

parameters.name: authId
parameters.description: Internal card authorization identifier associated with card transaction event. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: "8989"

parameters.name: authTs
parameters.description: Authorization timestamp. Can specify any timezone. Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2024-01-23T04:56:07.000+00:00"

parameters.name: acctOpenToBuy
parameters.description: The cardholder's available funds, also known as open to buy. Amount is checked during authorization validation to confirm the cardholder has sufficient funds to perform a transaction. Pattern: Integer or decimal amount Example: '200.00'

parameters.name: acctCity
parameters.description: Cardholderâ€™s city. Pattern: Max 30 characters: letters, spaces, hyphen and period Example: "Salt Lake City"

parameters.name: acctState
parameters.description: Cardholderâ€™s state or province for non US countries. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "Washington"

parameters.name: acctZip
parameters.description: Cardholderâ€™s postal code (e.g. US ZIP code or local postal code). Pattern: Min 5 characters and max 20 characters Example: "98101"

parameters.name: acctCountry
parameters.description: Cardholderâ€™s two-digit country code. See the IBAN Alpha-2 codes for details. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "US"

parameters.name: acctStartDate
parameters.description: Start date-time for the account was marked ready to use (e.g. account open or account funded date). Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2020-10-12T10:45:21.000+00:00"

parameters.name: cardActivateDate
parameters.description: Date-time for when the card was activated. Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2020-10-10T08:12:35.000+00:00"

parameters.name: cardStatus
parameters.description: Status for the card. Pattern: Max 10 character Example: "Active"

parameters.name: cardCredLim
parameters.description: Credit limit of the cardholderâ€™s account as whole or decimal amount. Pattern: Integer or decimal number Example: '1000'

parameters.name: merchantAssertsAuthenticationAttempted
parameters.description: Specifies whether the merchant/acquirer attempted to authenticate the buyer using 3-D Secure. True if attempted, False if the merchant/acquirer did not attempt. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: transactionCity
parameters.description: Merchant's city. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: Seattle

parameters.name: transactionZip
parameters.description: Postal code (US zip code or local postal code) where the transaction or event was performed. Pattern: Min 5 characters and max 20 characters Example: "98102"

parameters.name: isCardNotPresent
parameters.description: Whether a card was present during a transaction or event. True is card-not-present; False is card-present. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isCardholderNotPresent
parameters.description: Whether a card was present during a transaction or event. True is card-not-present; False is card-present. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isDomestic
parameters.description: Whether this is a domestic transaction. True is a domestic transaction; False for an international transaction. Definition of domestic at the discretion of the client. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: merchantDesc
parameters.description: Card acceptor name/location. See Data element 43 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 50 characters Example: "ROSS"

parameters.name: merchantId
parameters.description: Card acceptor identification code. See Data element 42 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 15 characters Example: "Ross_1234"

parameters.name: networkName
parameters.description: The card network. Acceptable values are: Visa, Mastercard, Discover, American Express, JCB, UnionPay, Accel, Star, Allpoint. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "Visa"

parameters.name: requestedAmount
parameters.description: The requested amount. Pattern: Integer or decimal amount Example: '85'

parameters.name: isContactless
parameters.description: Whether this is a transaction is contactless. True is a contactless transaction. Definition of contactless is at the discretion of the client. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isMagStripeRead
parameters.description: Whether the cardâ€™s magnetic stripe was swiped. True is yes. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isRecurring
parameters.description: Whether the transaction is a recurring bill payment.True is for a recurring bill payment. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isTransactionEmv
parameters.description: Whether the transaction used an EMV chip.True for when an EMV chip was used. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: threedsecureIndicator
parameters.description: Whether the transaction is 3-D Secure. True if the transaction was authenticated using 3-D Secure. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: acquirerInstitutionIdCode
parameters.description: Acquiring institution identification code. See Data element 32 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 6 characters Example: "INST_12"

parameters.name: mcc
parameters.description: Merchant category code, also known as the MCC. This indicates the type of merchant at the point of sale, such as supermarket, auto supply, etc. Codes are defined in the ISO 18245. See Data element 18 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: "6011"

parameters.name: messageTypeIndicator
parameters.description: Message type indicator for the authorization message being sent by the card network.See Data element 22 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: "0180"

parameters.name: posEntryModeFull
parameters.description: Point of service (POS) entry mode code. See Data element 22 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "05"

parameters.name: transTypeCode
parameters.description: Cardholder transaction type code. See Data element 3 subfield 1 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "01"

parameters.name: aav
parameters.description: Result from validating the 3-D Secure Accountholder authentication value. Accepted values: 'Y'- Validated, 'F' - Failed, 'N' - Not present. Pattern: Max 1 character Example: "Y"

parameters.name: avs
parameters.description: Result from validating the 3-D Secure Accountholder authentication value. Accepted values: 'Y'- Validated, 'F' - Failed, 'N' - Not present. Pattern: Max 1 character Example: "Y"

parameters.name: pin
parameters.description: Indicates the status of the pin. Accepted values: 'Y' - Validated, 'F' - Failed, 'N' - Not present, 'L' - Locked, 'M' - PIN not set, 'B' - Blocked). Pattern: Max 1 character Example: "N"

parameters.name: riskCode
parameters.description: Risk code sent by card network. Pattern: Max 3 characters Example: "675"

parameters.name: transactionCountry
parameters.description: Two character identifier for the country where the transaction was performed. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "US"

parameters.name: transactionState
parameters.description: State where the transaction was performed. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "Washington"

parameters.name: transactionStateFull
parameters.description: Full province name where transaction occurred. This is only for international transactions. Leave empty for US based transactions. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "Ontario"

parameters.name: riskScore
parameters.description: Visa Advanced Authorization (VAA) risk score ranging from 0 to 99 or Mastercard Decision Intelligence (DI) score ranging from 0 to 999. Pattern: Max 4 digits Example: 56

parameters.name: acctStatus
parameters.description: Status of the account. Pattern: Max 15 characters Example: "Active"

parameters.name: acctActive
parameters.description: Whether the account is active. True for when the account is active. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: cardholderAppDate
parameters.description: Date-time the cardholder applied for an account. Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2020-10-10T08:12:35.000+00:00"

parameters.name: pinFailDate
parameters.description: Date of last PIN failure. Pattern: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss Example: "2023-05-10T02:48:38.000+00:00"

parameters.name: isEcommerce
parameters.description: Whether this was an ecommerce transaction. True is for ecommerce transactions. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isMerchantAuthAssertionsValidated
parameters.description: Whether the AAV card value was validated and passed validation. True when the AVV card is validated and passed. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: aavIndicator
parameters.description: Indicates whether the AAV was authenticated or if an authentication attempt was made. Pattern: 'Y' Example: 'Y'

parameters.name: rawEci
parameters.description: The ECI sent in the transaction message. This is specific to the card network. Possible values include: 05 (Visa), 212 (MasterCard), 5 (Discover), etc. See Data element 48 Sub Element 42. Pattern: Max 3 characters Example: "05"

parameters.name: merchantAssertsDataProtection
parameters.description: True if the merchant/acquirer asserts that the communication channel between the buyer and the merchant is encrypted (e.g. with TLS/HTTPS). False if the merchant/acquirer makes no guarantee about the security of the communication channel with the buyer (e.g. uses HTTP). Proceed with caution when this field is False. A malicious third party could have compromised the transaction. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: merchantAssertsAuthenticated
parameters.description: Whether the merchant authenticated the buyer with 3-D Secure. True if the merchant/acquirer asserts that it authenticated the buyer using 3-D Secure and obtained a valid CAVV/AAV from the card network or Galileo. False if the merchant/acquirer makes no assertion whether the buyer is fully authenticated using 3-D Secure. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: emvCvn
parameters.description: Cryptogram version number for the EMV transaction. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "20"

parameters.name: emvCvr
parameters.description: Card verification results for the EMV transaction. Pattern: Max 12 characters Example: "a00120400400"

parameters.name: emvDki
parameters.description: Derivative Key Index (DKI) for the EMV transaction. See Data element 55 for 9F10 value. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "65"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceType
parameters.description: Visa only. Type of device used at the provisioning time from ISO8583. See Data element 125. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "dtype_123"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceLanguage
parameters.description: Three letter code for device_language at the provisioning time. See ISO 639.2 standards. Pattern: Max 3 characters Example: "eng"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceId
parameters.description: Device ID at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "108998A103804F45740927FF9984ML91J43R"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceNumber
parameters.description: Device phone number at the provisioning time when applicable. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 12 characters Example: "+18888888888"

parameters.name: provisioningLocation
parameters.description: Latitude and longitude with 2 digits of precision. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "+37.78/-122.43"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceIp
parameters.description: IP address of the device at the provisioning time. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "12.45.65.123"

parameters.name: provisioningDeviceScore
parameters.description: Wallet device score at the provisioning time. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "78"

parameters.name: provisioningAccountScore
parameters.description: Account score at the provisioning time. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "5"

parameters.name: provisioningPanSource
parameters.description: Identifies the method which the cardholder is attempting to tokenize a primary account number. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "02"

parameters.name: provisioningAccountEmailAddr
parameters.description: Account email address at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "someemail@gmail.com"

parameters.name: provisioningCorrelationId
parameters.description: correlation_id at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "D0000000000000"

parameters.name: provisioningPaymentAppInstanceId
parameters.description: payment_app_instance_id at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "98HAKDSFNQ84R8109R412IU3NRKABSF230"

parameters.name: provisioningCardholderName
parameters.description: Cardholder name at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "Sam Smith"

parameters.name: provisioningTokenizationRecommendation
parameters.description: Tokenization decision suggested by the wallet provider. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 1 characters Example: "2"

parameters.name: provisioningTokenizationRecommendationStandardVer
parameters.description: The version of the standards the wallet provider is using to determine the suggested tokenization recommendation. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "tokenstdvar_345"

parameters.name: provisioningTokenizationRecommendationReasonCode
parameters.description: Indicates the specific reason the wallet provider is suggesting the tokenization recommendation. See Data element 125 for Visa or DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 20 characters Example: "00088C"

parameters.name: provisioningActiveTokens
parameters.description: active_tokens at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: 22

parameters.name: provisioningTokenType
parameters.description: Mastercard only. Contains a value indicating the type of requested token. See DE 124 for Mastercard. Pattern: Max 1 character Example: "C"

parameters.name: provisioningConsumerIdentifier
parameters.description: consumer_identifier at the time of provisioning. Pattern: Max 60 characters Example: "cid_777"

parameters.name: isPartialAuthSupported
parameters.description: Whether the account supports partial authorizations. True for an account that supports partial authorization. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isCardEmv
parameters.description: Whether the card is EMV capable. True if card is EMV enabled. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isEmvFallback
parameters.description: Whether the transaction is when a card product is EMV and the terminal where the transaction is performed is EMV enabled but the transaction is non-EMV. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isFinalCompletion
parameters.description: Whether it is the last preauthorization after multiple preauths that are tied together have been performed and acts as a complete advice/authorization. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isIncrementalAuth
parameters.description: Whether it is part of an incremental authorization tied to other purchases that will settle at the same time (e.g. multiple purchases from a mini-fridge in a hotel). Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: isTerminalEmv
parameters.description: Whether the terminal is EMV capable. True when EMV is enabled. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: avsRequested
parameters.description: Whether AVS was requested. True when requested. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: currencyCodeBilling
parameters.description: Currency Code, Cardholder billing. See Data element 51 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 3 characters Example: "371"

parameters.name: currencyCodeTransaction
parameters.description: Currency Code, Transaction. See Data element 49 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 3 characters Example: "304"

parameters.name: merchantTerminalId
parameters.description: Card Acceptor Terminal Identification Code. See Data element 41 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 8 characters Example: "05940594"

parameters.name: posConditionCode
parameters.description: Visa only. SMS POS Condition. See Data element 25 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 2 characters Example: "89"

parameters.name: posData
parameters.description: Mastercard only. POS Data. See Data element 61 of the ISO message. Pattern: Max 30 characters Example: 00000000030000040000012039410324

parameters.name: isHighRisk
parameters.description: Flag to indicate whether card is high risk. Pattern: True or False Example: True

parameters.name: arqc
parameters.description: A cryptogram that is generated by the chip on a card during a chip transaction and sent to Galileo to validate that the source of the transaction is legitimate. Pattern: Max 1 characters Example: N

parameters.name: cvv1Status
parameters.description: Indicates status of CVV1. Accepted values: 'Y' - Verified, 'N' - Failed, 'None' - No CVV1 Passed. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: 'Y'

parameters.name: cvv2Status
parameters.description: Indicates status of CVV2. Accepted values: 'Y' - Verified, 'N' - Failed, 'None' - No CVV2 Passed. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: 'N'

parameters.name: cvv3Status
parameters.description: Indicates status of CVV3. Accepted values: 'Y' - Verified, 'N' - Failed, 'None' - No CVV3 Passed. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: 'N'

parameters.name: offlinePinStatus
parameters.description: Indicates the status of the offline pin. Accepted values: 'Y' - Verified, 'N' - Failed, 'E' - Offline Pin Try Count Exceeded, 'P' - Failed or tries exceeded, but within risk parameters, 'None' - No Offline PIN verification performed. Pattern: Max 4 characters Example: 'N'

api_reference.title: Get Instant Verification
api_reference.description: Use the Get Instant Verification API to validate the ownership and authenticity of an account. This endpoint returns risk levels, account existence, and associated metadata to help determine if an account is valid and if its owner is correctly identified. It provides detailed risk assessments for multiple use cases associated with an external bank account validation, such as ACH transactions, wire transactions, risk checks before account linking, and potential AML mitigation. See About Galileo Instant Verification for more details.

parameters.name: apiTransKey

api_reference.title: Transactions
api_reference.description: Use these endpoints to move funds into or out of a customer account or to retrieve lists of transactions. General information on transactions About Transactions About Card Transactions Transaction History Links to endpoints Get transactions for the specified account Get Account Overview â€” Transactions and other info for an account landing page Get Authorization History â€” Authorizations (not expired, settled, reversed, or completed) Get Transaction History â€” All posted transactions (no authorizations or backouts) Get All Transaction History â€” All transactions on the ledger Payments (deposits) Create Payment â€” Move funds into the account. See Creating a Payment for instructions. Get Direct Deposit Switch Token â€” Initiate direct deposit switch. See Direct Deposit Switch for instructions. Adjustments (withdrawals and administrative adjustments) Create Adjustment â€” See Creating an Adjustment for instructions. Transfers (account-to-account transfers) Create Account Transfer â€” See Creating an Internal Transfer for instructions. Fees Assess Fee â€” See About Fees for instructions. Holds Create Hold ACH (bank-to-bank transfers) â€” See ACH Endpoints for instructions: Add ACH Account â€” Add a remote account for private individuals Add ACH Account Corporate â€” Add a remote account for corporate entities Create ACH Transaction â€” Create an ACH transaction (credit or debit) to an ACH account. Billpay (checks or electronic payments to billers) â€” See Creating a Billpay Transaction for instructions. Add Paper Biller â€” Add a biller for paper checks Add RPPS Biller â€” Add a biller for electronic payments Create Bill Payment â€” Create a bill paymentâ€”scheduled or manualâ€”to a paper or electronic biller

api_reference.title: Account Events Webhook
api_reference.description: Galileo POSTs to /AccountEvent to send Account Events to the client. An Account Event is triggered when an event occurs on an account (card activated, updated profile, card shipped, etc.). Requests The event data (described in the index pages that follow) will be in the body of the request, as JSON or form data. JSON example (application/json) JSON{ "type": "card_shipped", "account_id": "2011", "balance": "500.00", "cad": "12534", "pmt_ref_no": "155200002022", "prod_id": "1701", "prog_id": "305", "timestamp": "2019-10-09 11:20:33 MST", "msg_event_id": "1234567891" } Form example (application/x-www-form-urlencoded) type=card_shipped&prod_id=1619&prog_id=255&pmt_ref_no=199999999998&open_to_buy=4.05&timestamp=2019-10-09+11%3A20%3A33+MST Responses Valid values for success_code. ValueDescriptionRetransmit0SuccessNo1Parameters do not pass validation (parsing error)No2Cardholder account not in systemNo3General system failureNo4Authentication failedNo5Not ready to accept messagesYes JSON response example JSON{ "success_code": "0" } XML responses should use the webhook name (AccountEvent) as the envelope. XML example XML<AccountEvent><success_code>0</success_code></AccountEvent>

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: Encryption-Type
parameters.description: Signature algorithm. For now, always "HMAC-SHA256".

parameters.name: User-ID
parameters.description: Identifies request as coming from Galileo. Hard-coded to "galileo".

parameters.name: Date
parameters.description: UTC timestamp when request is sent. Format: "<timestamp><timezone>" where timestamp = YYYYMMDD:HHMMSS and timezone = UTC. Example: 20170504:141752UTC.

parameters.name: Signature
parameters.description: Signature of request. See overview for more details.

parameters.name: success_code
parameters.description: Response ("success") codes. Possible values: 0 - Success 1 - Parameters do not pass validation 2 - Cardholder account not in system 3 - General system failure 4 - Authentication failed 5 - Not ready to accept messages. Event will be retransmitted. For all but 5, the event will not be retransmitted. 0 1 2 3 4 5

api_reference.title: ACH Debit Webhook
api_reference.description: Use the ACH Debit webhook to approve or deny incoming ACH debits. Use the response_code field in the response to communicate your decision to Galileo.

parameters.name: account_number
parameters.description: Galileo Payment Reference Number for the account Example: "999200002022"

parameters.name: account_status
parameters.description: Account status code. See the possible values in the Account Statuses enumeration. Example: "N"

parameters.name: transaction_amount
parameters.description: The amount of the ACH debit. Example: 150.00

parameters.name: currency
parameters.description: The three-digit currency code for the amounts. ISO 4217 Numeric Currency Code. 3 digits. Example: "840"

parameters.name: available_funds
parameters.description: Amount of funds available to the account holder. Example: 500.00

parameters.name: ach_name
parameters.description: Name of the ACH account holder. Example: "John Doe"

parameters.name: recipient
parameters.description: Name of the ODFI that receives the debited funds. Example: "Widgets Incorporated"

parameters.name: sec
parameters.description: The three-character standard entry class (SEC) code. Example: "WEB"

parameters.name: is_international
parameters.description: Whether this is an international transaction. Example: "false"

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: Description from the ACH header. Example: "PAYROLL "

parameters.name: timestamp
parameters.description: Timestamp when this webhook message was sent. Format is <timestamp><timezone> where timestamp is YYYYmmdd:HHMMSS and timezone is always MST. Example: "20270315:121504MST"

parameters.name: transaction_id
parameters.description: The unique identifier of the ACH transaction. Also called ach_trans_id and deposit_transaction_id in the Program API. Example: 32146803

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The version of this API. Hard-coded to "1.0".

parameters.name: batch_header
parameters.description: The batch header for the Nacha file that contained this ACH debit entry detail record. Example: "5225WIDGET INC DISCRETIONARY DATA 1234567890POSPAYROLL 2027052003070642123456780000001"

parameters.name: source_trace
parameters.description: The source trace number from the ACH record. Example: "123456781234567"

parameters.name: jwt
parameters.description: The JSON web token (JWT) that authenticates the HTTP request from Galileo. See the security overview for more information and an example.

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: response_code
parameters.description: Response code indicating how to process the ACH debit transaction. Possible response codes: 00 â€” Approve R01 â€” Reject; Insufficient funds R07 â€” Reject; Authorization revoked by customer R08 â€” Reject; Payment stopped R10 â€” Reject; Customer advises not authorized R16 â€” Reject; Bank account frozen R20 â€” Reject; Non-payment bank account 98 â€” System Error; Reject and do not retry 99 â€” System Error; Retry later You can use 99 to tell Galileo to retry later if your product is configured for retries.

api_reference.title: Authorization Events Webhook
api_reference.description: Galileo POSTs to /Authorization to send Authorization Events to the client. An Authorization Event is triggered when a card financial transaction with an association occurs. This includes card authorizations and denied card authorizations due to invalid PIN, insufficient funds, inactive card, etc. Requests The event data (described in the index pages that follow) will be in the body of the request, as JSON or form data. JSON example (application/json) JSON{ "type": "denied_auth_gas", "account_id": "2011", "amount": "10.25", "balance": "500.00", "card_id": "12534", "mcc": "5712", "merch_loc": "NEW YORK, NY", "merch_name": "Widgets Incorporated", "merch_num": "L4DIV6D5LM4X7LF", "network": "V", "pmt_ref_no": "155200002022", "prod_id": "1701", "prog_id": "305", "timestamp": "2019-10-09 11:20:33 MST", "auth_id": "12303090" } Form example (application/x-www-form-urlencoded) type=denied_auth_gas&prod_id=1504&prog_id=255&pmt_ref_no=199999999998&merchant_name=DISCOUNT+FM+1&merchant_number=231000000129001&mcc=5541&merch_loc=ARCHER%2C+FLUS&auth_tran_type=5&amount=30.65&network=V&open_to_buy=2.95&auth_id=29143890&timestamp=2019-10-09+11%3A20%3A33+MST&account_id=388750&card_id=740724 Responses ValueDescriptionRetransmit0SuccessNo1Parameters do not pass validation (parsing error)No2Cardholder account not in systemNo3General system failureNo4Authentication failedNo5Not ready to accept messagesYes JSON example JSON{ "success_code": "0" } XML responses should use the webhook name (Authorization) as the envelope. XML example XML<Authorization><success_code>0</success_code></Authorization>

parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.description: Signature algorithm. For now, always "HMAC-SHA256".

parameters.name: Date
parameters.description: UTC timestamp when request is sent. Format: "<timestamp><timezone>" where timestamp = YYYYMMDD:HHMMSS and timezone = UTC. Example: 20170504:141752UTC.

parameters.name: success_code

Possible values: 0 - Success 1 - Parameters do not pass validation 2 - Cardholder account not in system 3 - General system failure 4 - Authentication failed 5 - Not ready to accept messages. Event will be retransmitted. For all but 5, the event will not be retransmitted. 0 1 2 3 4 5

api_reference.title: Auth API Webhook 2.0
api_reference.description: With the Auth API 2.0 webhook, you can participate in authorization decisions. For this webhook there is only one verb: POST. Galileo sends information about the authorization request in the body of the HTTP request, in JSON. Your decision should be in the body of the HTTP response. In the authorization information that Galileo sends, the response_code is the current response code to be returned to the merchant, unless you override it. Use the response_code field in the HTTP response body to override the authorization response code, as desired. See the Authorization Controller API guide for more information. ðŸ“˜About the field propertiesGalileo initializes the webhook payload by setting all fields to null. As values come in with the ISO 8583 authorization request, Galileo populates the respective payload fields with the data the network sends, which can include empty strings (" "). This documentation shows the field properties (data type, nullability, required) that are most likely. However, variations by network and transaction type mean that a few of the values passed in the webhook payload can vary from what is shown here.

parameters.name: auth_type
parameters.description: All transactions are grouped into three basic message types: Auth â€” Authorization request. MTI x1xx (authorization or preauthorization over credit rails or preauthorization over debit rails) or x2xx (authorization over debit rails). Advice â€” Notification of a completed transaction. MTI xx2x. Only a 00 response code is permitted. Reversal â€” A reversal of a previous authorization. MTI x4xx. May or may not reference the previous authorization.

parameters.name: transaction_type
parameters.description: The transaction type indicates at a lower level what kind of transaction this is. This field is used to differentiate merchant credits, ATMs, balance inquiries, etc. Preauth â€” A preauthorization for an estimated amount. Often followed by a completion advice. Auth â€” Conventional authorization request. Also used with advices and reversals. ATM â€” ATM withdrawal. Cash Advance â€” Cash advance from a teller. Balance Inquiry â€” Balance inquiry from an ATM. Merchant Credit â€” A credited amount from a merchant. Usually does not reference a previous authorization. Adjustment â€” Debit adjustment, unrelated to a previous authorization. The merchant is adjusting a cardholder balance. Payment â€” Loading funds onto a card. Tokenization â€” A request to tokenize a card for use in a mobile wallet or a request from a merchant to validate a tokenized card for payment.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique identifier for this authorization. Example: "DHWJtI8zRjuDcgF8hru3oQ"

parameters.name: timestamp
parameters.description: Date and time when the webhook was sent by Galileo. Format is <timestamp><timezone>, where timestamp is YYYYMMDD:HHMMSS and timezone is always MST, which is Arizona time (GMT -0700). Example: "20250315:121504MST"

parameters.name: network
parameters.description: Card network name. Possible values: Visa Allpoint Discover Mastercard Star Pulse

parameters.name: subnetwork
parameters.description: The subnetwork name. This is the same as network if there is no subnetwork. Possible values: Visa Visa Interlink Visa PLUS Mastercard Banknet Mastercard Debit Switch Discover Allpoint Star Star MoneyPass Star Presto Pulse

parameters.name: mcc
parameters.description: Merchant category code. This value does not include leading zeros. Example: 5992

parameters.name: mti
parameters.description: Message-type indicator, as defined by ISO 8583. See Message types in the Authorization Controller API guide. Example: "0200"

parameters.name: international
parameters.description: Whether this is an international transaction.

parameters.name: response_code
parameters.description: Authorization response code, which specifies whether a transaction is approved or denied. See the Authorization Response Codes enumeration for possible values. Example: "05"

parameters.name: auth_id
parameters.description: Galileo-generated ID for the authorization. Use this ID to track the transaction throughout the Galileo system. For an explanation of how these IDs are generated, see Authorization identifiers in the Transaction IDs guide. Example: 13371854

parameters.name: partial_supported
parameters.description: Whether the merchant supports partial authorizations.

parameters.name: incremental_auth
parameters.description: If this authorization is part of an an incremental sequence, this field is true and original_id contains the auth_id of the previous authorization in the sequence.

parameters.name: entry_type
parameters.description: Method of entering the PAN, also known as POS entry mode. See DE022 Codes to correlate with the numerical values. Possible values: Card Not Present â€” Online, mail order or telephone order Card On File â€” Mastercard only. Card number is kept on file E-Commerce â€” Mastercard only. The card was used on an ecommerce site EMV Chip â€” The card has an EMV chip that was inserted in an EMV slot EMV Contactless â€” Contactless transaction with EMV chip card EMV Fallback â€” Unable to use the EMV chip: fallback to magstripe Magnetic Stripe â€” The magnetic stripe was read Contactless â€” Contactless transaction with magstripe card Manual â€” Manually entered information Other â€” None of the above

parameters.name: pin_entry_capability
parameters.description: Condition of the PIN pad at the point of sale. See DE022 Codes to correlate with the numerical values. Possible values: Capable â€” Terminal has PIN-entry capability Incapable â€” Terminal has no PIN-entry capability Inoperative â€” Terminal has PIN-entry capability but it is not working Other â€” Unknown PIN-entry capability, or not applicable.

parameters.name: original_id
parameters.description: The auth_id of a previous authorization that is linked to this authorization. For reversals or completions, this is the auth_id of the authorization that is being reversed or completed. For incremental sequences, this is the auth_id of the previous authorization in the sequence. Example: 13663253

parameters.name: risk_score
parameters.description: The risk score provided by the network. Mastercard range: 0â€“999, Visa range: 01â€“99. Higher values indicate higher risk. Product settings determine whether the threshold was exceeded. Example: "23"

parameters.name: token_type
parameters.description: If this is a tokenized transaction, its type. Possible values: Apple Inc Google Inc. Masterpass Merchant Microsoft Samsung Corporation Visa Checkout

parameters.name: bai
parameters.description: Business application identifier. Visa only. See the Business Application Identifier enumeration for possible values. Example: "FD"

parameters.name: risk_code
parameters.description: Mastercard only. Fraud reason code. Indicates the key factors that influenced the value in risk_score. Example: "58"

parameters.name: eligible_for_balance_return
parameters.description: Whether the cardholder's balance can be returned. This field is always true when transaction_type: Balance Inquiry. See Balance-inquiry responses in the Authorization Controller API guide for information on returning balances in the response to this message.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: Auth API version of this webhook. Example: "2.0"

parameters.name: merchant_advice_code
parameters.description: Mastercard only. Contains the supported merchant advice code (MAC), if applicable: 03, 40, 41, or 43. The GMACD parameter must be set to Y to enable MAC decisioning.

parameters.name: latest_incremental_id
parameters.description: The auth_id of the previous authorization in an incremental sequence when incremental_auth: true. This field contains the same information as original_id and is present only by request. Example: 13371854

parameters.name: original_incremental_id
parameters.description: The auth_id of the first authorization in an incremental sequence when incremental_auth: true. This field is present only by request. Example: 13369203

parameters.name: account_attack_intelligence_score
parameters.description: Visa only. A score for CNP transactions to evaluate risk of enumeration attacks. Field 104, Dataset 5B, Tag 85. Valid values are 01-99 or null. Lower scores mean less risk. Example: "24"

parameters.name: service_processing_type
parameters.description: Visa only. Service processing type for scheduled, deferred OCTs. See Service Processing Types for valid values. Field 104 Dataset 57 Tag 80. Example: "03"

parameters.name: is_in_person_tap_transaction
parameters.description: Visa only. Whether this is a direct in-person tap transaction. Applies only to OCTs and AFTs. Field 34.

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: avs_response
parameters.description: Use this field to override avs_result, if you believe avs_result is wrong. See AVS Codes for valid values. Example: "Y"

parameters.name: override_limit
parameters.description: Use this field to override authorization limits, if permitted. If this field is true then any limits that would be reached are overridden. Example: true

parameters.name: partial_amount
parameters.description: If response_code indicates a partial approval (10 or 87), this is the partial amount to approve. Example: 5.00

parameters.name: transfer_prn
parameters.description: If you want to perform a transfer to cover a lack of funds, this is the PRN of the account to supply the funds. Example: "155200002717"

parameters.name: transfer_amount
parameters.description: The amount to transfer from the transfer_prn to the cardholder account. Example: 20.00

parameters.name: source_transfer_type
parameters.description: The transaction type for the adjustment on the source account in transfer_prn. Use the value that Galileo supplied. Case sensitive. Default: pc. Example: "lm"

parameters.name: dest_transfer_type
parameters.description: The transaction type for the adjustment to the cardholder account. Use the value that Galileo supplied. Case sensitive. Default: PC Example: "LM"

parameters.name: available_balance
parameters.description: If eligible_for_balance_return: true AND you hold the ledger for the card account, populate this field with the card account's available balance to spend before the transaction is performed. Otherwise, Galileo sends the balance it has in the response message. The amount should be in the account currency. (The card networks will perform currency conversion as needed.) Example: 250.00

parameters.name: savings_balance
parameters.description: If eligible_for_balance_return: true AND you hold the ledger for the cardholder's savings account, populate this field with the savings account balance in the currency of the account. Otherwise, Galileo sends the balance it has in the response message. Example: 4000.00

parameters.name: available_credit
parameters.description: If eligible_for_balance_return: true AND you hold the ledger for the cardholder's credit account, populate this field with the credit limit remaining in the currency of the account. Otherwise, Galileo sends the remaining limit it has in the response message. Example: 1500.00

api_reference.title: Auth API Webhook 3.0
api_reference.description: With the Auth API 3.0 webhook, you can participate in authorization decisions. For this webhook there is only one verb: POST. Galileo sends information about the authorization request in the body of the HTTP request, in JSON. Your decision should be in the body of the HTTP response. In the authorization information that Galileo sends, the response_code is the current response code to be returned to the merchant, unless you override it. Use the response_code field in the HTTP response body to override the authorization response code, as desired. See the Authorization Controller API guide for more information. ðŸ“˜About the field propertiesGalileo initializes the webhook payload by setting all fields to null. As values come in with the ISO 8583 authorization request, Galileo populates the respective payload fields with the data the network sends, which can include empty strings (" "). This documentation shows the field properties (data type, nullability, required) that are most likely. However, variations by network and transaction type mean that a few of the values passed in the webhook payload can vary from what is shown here. Open the Recipes below to see webhook examples that you can use for testing.

api_reference.title: Billpay Webhook
api_reference.description: Use the Billpay webhook to approve or deny billpay transactions. Use the response_code field in the response to communicate your decision to Galileo.

parameters.name: timestamp
parameters.description: Timestamp when this webhook message was sent. Format is <timestamp><timezone> where timestamp is YYYYmmdd:HHMMSS and timezone is always MST. Example: "20200315:121504MST"

parameters.name: billpay_trans_id
parameters.description: Unique Galileo billpay transaction ID. Example: 559386.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The version of this API. Hard-coded to "1.0".

parameters.name: jwt
parameters.description: The JSON web token (JWT) that authenticates the HTTP request from Galileo. See the security overview for more information and an example.

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: response_code
parameters.description: Response code indicating how to process the billpay transaction. Possible response codes: 00 â€” Approve 01 â€” Reject; Insufficient funds 98 â€” System Error; Reject and do not retry 99 â€” System Error; Retry later You can use 99 to tell Galileo to retry later if your product is configured for retries.

api_reference.title: Settlement Events Webhook
api_reference.description: Galileo POSTs to /Settlement to send Settlement Events to the client. A Settlement Event is triggered when a card financial transaction is settled or force posted. Requests The event data (described in the index pages that follow) will be in the body of the request, as JSON or form data. JSON example (application/json) JSON{ "type": "setl", "act_type": "VI", "amount": "10.75", "auth_id": "254568", "balance_id": "2011", "cad": "12534", "mcc": "5712", "merchant_location": "NEW YORK, NY", "merchant_name": "Widgets Incorporated", "merchant_number": "L4DIV6D5LM4X7LF", "network": "V", "open_to_buy": "500.00", "otype": "10", "pmt_ref_no": "155200002022", "prod_id": "1701", "prog_id": "305", "timestamp": "2019-10-09 11:20:33 MST" } Form example (application/x-www-form-urlencoded) type=setl&act_type=VI&amount=10.75&auth_id=254568&balance_id=2011&cad=12534&mcc=5712&merchant_location=NEW+YORK%2C+NY&merchant_name=Widgets+Incorporated&merchant_number=L4DIV6D5LM4X7LF&network=V&open_to_buy=500&otype=10&pmt_ref_no=155200002022&prod_id=1701&prog_id=305&timestamp=2019-10-09+11%3A20%3A33+MST Responses ValueDescriptionRetransmit0SuccessNo1Parameters do not pass validation (parsing error)No2Cardholder account not in systemNo3General system failureNo4Authentication failedNo5Not ready to accept messagesYes JSON example JSON{ "success_code": "0" } XML responses should use the webhook name (Settlement) as the envelope. XML example XML<Settlement><success_code>0</success_code></Settlement>

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: Encryption-Type
parameters.description: Signature algorithm. For now, always "HMAC-SHA256".

parameters.name: User-ID
parameters.description: Identifies request as coming from Galileo. Hard-coded to "galileo".

parameters.name: Date
parameters.description: UTC timestamp when request is sent. Format: "<timestamp><timezone>" where timestamp = YYYYMMDD:HHMMSS and timezone = UTC. Example: 20170504:141752UTC.

parameters.name: Signature
parameters.description: Signature of request. See overview for more details.

parameters.name: success_code
parameters.description: Response ("success") codes. Possible values: 0 - Success 1 - Parameters do not pass validation 2 - Cardholder account not in system 3 - General system failure 4 - Authentication failed 5 - Not ready to accept messages. Event will be retransmitted. For all but 5, the event will not be retransmitted. 0 1 2 3 4 5

api_reference.title: Transaction Events Webhook
api_reference.description: Galileo POSTs to /Transaction to send Transaction Events to the client. A Transaction Event is triggered for all other financial transactions that occur against an account, but don't go through an association (fee, payments, adjustments, etc.). Requests The event data (described in the index pages that follow) will be in the body of the request, as JSON or form data. JSON example (application/json) JSON{ "type": "ach_credit_fail", "account_id": "2011", "amount": "45.00", "pmt_ref_no": "155200002022", "prod_id": "1701", "prog_id": "305", "return_code": "R01", "source": "Chase Bank", "source_id": "6426460", "timestamp": "2019-10-09 11:20:33 MST" } Form example (application/x-www-form-urlencoded) type=ach_credit_fail&account_id=2011&amount=45&pmt_ref_no=155200002022&prod_id=1701&prog_id=305&return_code=R01&source=Chase+Bank&source_id=6426460&timestamp=2019-10-09+11%3A20%3A33+MST Responses ValueDescriptionRetransmit0SuccessNo1Parameters do not pass validation (parsing error)No2Cardholder account not in systemNo3General system failureNo4Authentication failedNo5Not ready to accept messagesYes JSON example JSON{ "success_code": "0" } XML responses should use the webhook name (Transaction) as the envelope. XML example XML<Transaction><success_code>0</success_code></Transaction>

parameters.name: X-Request-ID
parameters.description: A unique identifier for the HTTP request.

parameters.name: Encryption-Type
parameters.description: Signature algorithm. For now, always "HMAC-SHA256".

parameters.name: User-ID
parameters.description: Identifies request as coming from Galileo. Hard-coded to "galileo".

Event will be retransmitted. For all but 5, the event will not be retransmitted. 0 1 2 3 4 5
